original_data.question: A 2-month-old infant is brought to the emergency department by her mother due to a fall. Tearfully, the patient’s mother describes witnessing her child fall from the changing table. The patient was born prematurely at 36 weeks estimated gestational age via vacuum-assisted vaginal delivery. The patient is afebrile. Her vital signs include: blood pressure of 94/60 mm Hg, pulse 200/min, and respiratory rate 70/min. Physical examination reveals a subconjunctival hemorrhage in the left eye and multiple bruises on the chest and back. Which of the following is the best initial step in management of this patient’s condition?

model_response:
The patient’s presentation is consistent with physical abuse. The initial step in management is to ensure the child’s safety. This requires involvement of both medical and social services. The child should be admitted to the hospital and a thorough evaluation, including a CT scan of the head to rule out intracranial trauma, should be performed. Family counseling may be offered after an evaluation for medical and psychological conditions that may contribute to the abuse.

Answer: OPTION B IS CORRECT.</s><s>

question_entities.definition: A child between 1 and 23 months of age.
Hospital department responsible for the administration and provision of immediate medical or surgical care to the emergency patient.

Individuals participating in the health care system for the purpose of receiving therapeutic, diagnostic, or preventive procedures.
An infant born after 28 completed weeks of gestation and before 32 completed weeks of gestation.
Any period of seven consecutive days.

The age of the conceptus, beginning from the time of FERTILIZATION. In clinical obstetrics, the gestational age is often estimated from the onset of the last MENSTRUATION which is about 2 weeks before OVULATION and fertilization. It is also estimated to begin from fertilization, estrus, coitus, or artificial insemination.
Individuals participating in the health care system for the purpose of receiving therapeutic, diagnostic, or preventive procedures.
PRESSURE of the BLOOD on the ARTERIES and other BLOOD VESSELS.
A metric unit of length equal to one thousandth of a meter (10E-3 meter) or approximately 0.03937 inch.
The rhythmical expansion and contraction of an ARTERY produced by waves of pressure caused by the ejection of BLOOD from the left ventricle of the HEART as it contracts.
The rate of breathing (inhalation and exhalation) measured within in a unit time, usually expressed as breaths per minute.
Systematic and thorough inspection of the patient for physical signs of disease or abnormality.
Bleeding or escape of blood from a vessel.
The eye positioned in the left orbit.
The upper part of the trunk between the NECK and the ABDOMEN. It contains the chief organs of the circulatory and respiratory systems. (From Stedman, 25th ed)
The rear surface of an upright primate from the shoulders to the hip, or the dorsal surface of tetrapods.
Performing or possessing executive duties; acting as a supervisor or manager.
A description of the physiological status of a patient.
